articles.headline: As Jobs Lag, Fed Is Viewed as Unlikely to Do More
articles.snippet: The share of Americans holding jobs has failed to improve much over the last three years, but Federal Reserve officials show little interest in expanding their stimulus campaign.
articles.abstract: The share of Americans holding jobs has failed to improve much over the last three years, but Federal Reserve officials show little interest in expanding their stimulus campaign.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve is making modest progress in its push to reduce the unemployment rate. But that is not the jobs goal Congress actually established for the Fed. The central bank is supposed to be maximizing employment. And on that front, it is not making progress.

articles.headline: Massacre in Nigeria Spurs Outcry Over Military Tactics
articles.snippet: A gruesome assault that left scores of villagers dead has been blamed by survivors on revenge-seeking soldiers and has brought withering criticism at home and abroad.
articles.abstract: A gruesome assault that left scores of villagers dead has been blamed by survivors on revenge-seeking soldiers and has brought withering criticism at home and abroad.
articles.lead_paragraph: MAIDUGURI, Nigeria — Days later, the survivors’ faces tensed at the memory of the grim evening: soldiers dousing thatched-roof homes with gasoline, setting them on fire and shooting residents when they tried to flee. As the village went up in smoke, one said, a soldier threw a child back into the flames.

articles.headline: Even VW Now Feels the Weight of Europe’s Economic Troubles
articles.snippet: Vehicle sales on the Continent have declined to their lowest levels in decades.
articles.abstract: Vehicle sales on the Continent have declined to their lowest levels in decades.
articles.lead_paragraph: The troubled European car market is now dragging down even Volkswagen, the region’s leading automaker, as vehicle sales on the Continent have declined to their lowest levels in decades.

articles.headline: Flow of Tainted Water Is Latest Crisis at Japan Nuclear Plant
articles.snippet: Workers at the Fukushima Daiichi power plant were struggling to contain groundwater that was pouring into the plant’s reactor buildings by the minute.
articles.abstract: Workers at the Fukushima Daiichi power plant were struggling to contain groundwater that was pouring into the plant’s reactor buildings by the minute.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Two years after a triple meltdown that grew into the world’s second worst nuclear disaster, the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant is faced with a new crisis: a flood of highly radioactive wastewater that workers are struggling to contain.

articles.headline: Studying the Dark Art of Leaking Deal Talks
articles.snippet: A study by the Cass Business School in London found that leaks had fallen in recent years, and pointed to a strategy of how buyers and sellers approached leaks to gain an advantage. Andrew Ross Sorkin and Peter Lattman discuss the use of leaked in...
articles.abstract: A study by the Cass Business School in London found that leaks had fallen in recent years, and pointed to a strategy of how buyers and sellers approached leaks to gain an advantage. Andrew Ross Sorkin and Peter Lattman discuss the use of leaked information.

articles.headline: Technology Start-Ups Take Root in Berlin
articles.snippet: New companies are growing fast in the German capital, which with its stylish cool and cheap rents is becoming a vibrant home for young entrepreneurs.
articles.abstract: New companies are growing fast in the German capital, which with its stylish cool and cheap rents is becoming a vibrant home for young entrepreneurs.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Near the Rosenthaler Platz subway station here, signs of the city’s high-tech future blend seamlessly with its communist past.

articles.headline: Immigration Splits Senator From Mentor
articles.snippet: Jim DeMint, a former Republican senator, who helped kill legislation to overhaul immigration, finds Marco Rubio, his onetime protégé, on the other side of the issue.
articles.abstract: Jim DeMint, a former Republican senator, who helped kill legislation to overhaul immigration, finds Marco Rubio, his onetime protégé, on the other side of the issue.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Jim DeMint helped makeMarco Rubio a Senate star — and he could be forgiven for regretting it.

articles.headline: Another Executive Leaves JPMorgan, Raising Questions as Vote Nears
articles.snippet: The turnover at the highest levels of the bank continues just weeks before a shareholder vote decides whether to split the roles of chairman and chief executive.
articles.abstract: The turnover at the highest levels of the bank continues just weeks before a shareholder vote decides whether to split the roles of chairman and chief executive.
articles.byline: By Susanne Craig and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline: Amid Hunger Strike, Obama Renews Push to Close Cuba Prison
articles.snippet: President Obama said he would try again to close the Guantánamo prison, a goal that he all but abandoned in the face of opposition in Congress and that still faces steep challenges.
articles.abstract: President Obama said he would try again to close the Guantánamo prison, a goal that he all but abandoned in the face of opposition in Congress and that still faces steep challenges.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama said on Tuesday that he would recommit himself to closing the Guantánamo Bay prison, a goal that he all but abandoned in the face of Congressional opposition in his first term and that faces steep challenges now.
